summary: This document is an email chain from June 2020 between personnel from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and FBI NY CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) examiners. The emails discuss significant delays and logistical challenges in processing, transferring, and reviewing digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The correspondence reveals frustration over the inability to access and search the data, concerns about meeting discovery obligations, and the massive scale of the evidence (terabytes of data from numerous devices).

persons.name: Rozier
persons.role: U.S. Attorney's Office Case Team Member
persons.context: Mentioned as a potential participant in a conference call to discuss the evidence processing issues.

events.title: Delayed Evidence Processing Update
events.description: FBI CART informs the U.S. Attorney's Office that staffing issues and recent events have caused a 1-2 week delay in their estimate for completing the production of digital evidence from the Epstein searches.

events.title: Updated Device Descriptions Provided
events.description: An FBI NY CART Coordinator/Senior Examiner sends an updated list of seized digital evidence items to the U.S. Attorney's Office, noting that many thumb drives and SD cards have electronically reported serial numbers.

events.title: Request for Specific Device Identifiers
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office requests serial numbers and specific location data for each seized device to properly draft search warrants and differentiate between similar items.

events.title: Major Problems with Received Data Reported
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office details severe problems with over 1 million previously received documents, including an inability to link emails to attachments, mismatched control numbers, and invisible large files, rendering the data nearly unreviewable.

keyFacts: The FBI's Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York and U.S. Virgin Islands residences, including servers, laptops, phones, tablets, DVRs, and numerous loose storage devices.

Significant delays were caused by staffing reductions (down to one day a week in the office), the complexity of the data, and methodological disagreements over using the Relativity e-discovery tool for forensic review.

The U.S. Attorney's Office reported critical failures in earlier data transfers, receiving over 1 million documents in an unusable format where emails could not be linked to attachments and many files were inaccessible.
Investigators were seeking to obtain results from searches conducted in July and September (presumably 2019) before moving forward with possible additional charges in the case.
The evidence inventory included multiple copies of hard drives from a July 2007 search of one of Epstein's properties, indicating a long history of digital evidence collection.
